conversations.content: Siren's Song: Part One
Deep under the sea, there lived a songstress named Siren who had made music from the very moment of her birth.
The songs she sang on the seafloor became bubbles that floated up into a shimmering light. But she always wondered what that light was, and where, exactly, her songs went.
One day, Siren followed the bubbles and found they reached a world of serene blue skies and a dazzling sun.
Faced with such a beautiful sight, she could not help but express her joy by bursting into song.
As she was singing in the waves, a boy appeared on the shore. ＂Your song is beautiful!＂ he cried.
This praise caused her to sing all the louder—and because the language of music has no barriers, the girl from the sea and the boy from the land became fast friends.
Several years passed, and the boy grew into a young man. Soon, he told the girl the time had come for him to leave his town by the shore and venture across the ocean.
As she sang a song to bless him with safe passage on his journey, his eyes shone with all the radiance of a midsummer's night sky.
Several days after his ship left port, it met with a most fearsome storm. When the fish of the sea told Siren that the ship was on the verge of disaster, she rushed to the surface.
Her desperate song rang out in the ceaseless rain as she sought to use its echoes to find him.
Eventually she found him floating amidst the cold ocean waves. Taking his quickly cooling body onto her back, she raced for land as fast as she could travel.
When she finally reached land, she cried out for help. Soon, the people of a nearby village arrived and took the young man into their care.
The young man's life was saved. The worst was behind them, and their tale would close with a most happy ending...or so she thought.
Siren's Song: Part Two
One day, Siren used the power of her song to save a young man who had been lost at sea. Afterward, she thought all would be well... but there is more to the story.
Soon after the storm had passed, the surviving sailors came to Siren and accused her of great mischief.
＂You bewitched the winds and called that storm to sink our ship!＂ they raged. ＂And all so you could steal away that boy you love from his own people!＂
In truth, the wreck was the fault of the sailors' own carelessness. But they were loath to admit their own failings, and soon the story they told had been accepted as fact.
But as Siren began to protest their falsehoods, she learned something that shook her to the core:
Because of the accident, the young man had lost the ability to hear.
When she learned this, her body went numb. Somehow, she summoned the strength to dive back into the cold ocean depths, where she quickly broke down into sobs.
But even as she cried, the lie of the sailors continued to spread. Soon, her life had become little more than another terrifying tale of the sea.
The more she tried to stifle her tears, the more fell from her eyes. The more she tried to convince herself that she wasn't lonely, the more alone she felt.
She had legs to run, but was too terrified to move. She had a voice for song, but could only sing verses filled with melancholy—for she knew he would never again hear them.
If she sang, her song would turn to bubbles and vanish—but alas, the same could not be said of her soul. For she knew that no prince would ever come to save her.
No doubt this story was doomed to have a sad ending from the start. And yet, she couldn't help but hope that tomorrow might bring happiness with it anyway.
She silently wished that she might talk and sing in joy as she once did. That she might live out a tale of her own choosing once more...
